course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Introduction to Social Network Analysis
course.description: This course familiarizes students with the basic concepts of Social Network Analysis, their application in different Social Science fields, and teaches them how to analyse network data using open-source software. The course consists both of lectures and applied exercises, the latter culminating in a group project. Knowledge of basic statistics is recommended, but not required for this course.

reviews.author: I.048S96
reviews.title: A Great Introductory Course to Social Network Analysis (Which is a very interesting topic)
reviews.comment_content:
The content is well structured and sensibly paced.
[Below is from the "Syllabus" Section of CANVAS]

Week 1 (September 4-5th ):
Lecture: What is Social Network Analysis? What it is good for?
Lab: Getting started. Installing gephi, visone, and R. Introducing the project datasets
Tasks: fill out the online survey

Week 2 (September 11-12th):
Lecture: types of networks (directed, undirected, binary, weighted, bipartite). The parts that make up networks: nodes, ties, dyads (Chapter 1: 1.1-1.3)
Lab: opening different network files, matrices, edgelists. The class network,
Tasks: homework assignments, skim articles associated with project datasets of interest to you

Week 3 (September 18-19th):
Lecture: Data collection. Surveys and observational data (Chapter 2)
Lab: How to use filters, how to deal with large networks, more on visualizations in gephi.
Task: homework assignment

No class on September 25th (day after Mid-Autumn Festival)

Week 4-5 (September 26th & October 2nd):
Lecture: levels of analysis: node, dyads, triads, cliques, communities. (1.4-1.7 of Chapter 1, and section 3.1 and 3.3 of Chapter 3)
Lab: Filters (continued), centrality measures

Week 5-6 (October 3rd &9th):
Lecture: node level analysis (network positions): centrality, structural equivalence (Chapter 3)
Lab: centrality, structural equivalence

Week 6-7 (October 10th – October 16th): review and midterm exam

Week 8 (October 23-24th)
Lecture: dyads, triads, clustering; discuss midterm exam, poster, presentation
Lab: discuss and decide on rough outline of project idea

Week 9 (October 30-31st):
Lecture: cliques and communities, types of networks: behavior on networks / along network ties
Lab: visone, centrality, structural equivalence and clustering

Week 10 (November 6-7th):
Lecture: network models: Erdös-Renyi, preferential attachment, homophily, small world – descriptive statistics (Chapter 4)
Lab: Netlogo: network formation models, contagion models

Week 11 (November 13-14th):
Lecture: network models: Erdös-Renyi, preferential attachment, homophily, small world – inferential statistics (Chapter 4)
Lab: statnet (R): ERGM, 2nd half: work on projects

Week 12 (November 20-21st):
Lecture: Summary
Lab: work on projects

Week 13 (November 27-28th):
Lecture: Project presentations
Lab: review for final exam
reviews.comment_teaching:
Her teaching is one of the best I have seen in the SOSC department. She makes sure everyone follows the tutorial sessions, and thoroughly answers all the questions students ask.

I don't think attendance is necessary because all of the materials are inside the presentation slides. But because it's a small class, the Professor will remember who comes and does not come to classes.

If you want a good grade, visit her office at least once every week to get help on the assignment or advice on the project (Unfortunately, the TA is very cautious about helping students on assignments and projects, so the Professor is more helpful).

For midterms, concentrate on centrality measures.
For finals, make sure you understand all slides on ERGMs. (I didn't focus on ERGMs and had difficult time in the final questions...)
reviews.comment_grading:
The professor is very lenient and is willing to give good scores to all students. However, there are many upper-class students (a few postgraduate students), so it may not be easy to achieve the highest score (A+).

[Assignments (6 in Total, 1 Optional)]
Homework Assignment 1: Mean = 26.7, Max = 28.5/30 [.]
Homework Assignment 2: Mean = 21.8, Max = 25/25 [.]
Homework Assignment 3: Mean = 4.6, Max = 5/5 [.]
Homework Assignment 4: Mean = 20.3, Max =25/25 [.]
Homework Assignment 5: Mean = 27.3, Max = 30/30 [.]
Homework Assignment 6: Mean = ??, Max = ?? (Didn't do it)

*Assignment #3 was project-related and was only 5 points worth
*If you ruin any of the assignments, you can choose to do assignment #6 and replace it with the one you didn't do well.
*Given that the assignment is only 20% and total point adds up to more than 100, the score difference in assignments don't mean a lot.

[Midterm (20%)]
Mean = 61.4/74, Max = 69, Min = 44/74

[Final (20%)]
Yet to be Announced (/77). The Final Exam was not as easy as the Midterm exam.

[Final Presentation (15%)]
Mean = 17.4, Max = 20, Min = 13/20

[Final Poster (20%)]
Mean = 18.5, Max = 20, Min = 15/20

[Attendance and Participation (5%)]
Yet to be announced. However, the Professor will probably grant high scores for attendance even though many students didn't actually come to class (or were late).
reviews.comment_workload:
Overall, the course has mediocre workload, but it is manageable. The course has a midterm and final exam, five assignments (may be more for future classes), and a project.

[Assignment]
The biggest problem is that the assignments are handed out on Tuesday and you have to submit the assignment on Friday of the same week. The lecture sessions were on Wednesdays so you only have two full days to complete the assignment.

The assignment is meant to take 1-2 hours, but it should take at least 3 hours to get an acceptable grade in the assignment. It is not very difficult but it does take some time to figure out the right answers.

[Project (2 person group, but can ask for expansion)]
The project is a poster project where you have to make a poster and present (with a separate presentation) your research in 10 minutes. The grading is quite lenient, but you should meet with the professor to confirm if what you are doing is what she wants. She will give good scores if you accept her advice.

[Reading]
She assigns readings (not always, 4 chapters over the semester), but the reading material are not covered in the exams. It is only for your understanding. You may choose not to do it.

reviews.author: economist
reviews.title: A relaxing and interesting course
reviews.comment_content:
Caveat: This course is NOT about social media but the construction of social networks in a social science context.

I will put the emphasis in parenthesis (I won't guarantee they will appear in your exams but I think they are important from my point of view):
- Network data collection bias (Q: Prepare some DIY examples)
- Centralities: degree centrality, betweenness, closeness, eigenvector centrality (Q: Page Rank --> important pages are pointed from other (more) important pages)
- Dyads, structural equivalence, geodesic distance, homophily (Q: Give explanations using the concept of homophily)
- Triads, clustering, cliques, cores (Q: calculation of local/global clustering coefficients)
- Characteristics of different networks (Q: understand different properties and the data generating process of each of them)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great.
A lot of breakout room (or toilet break??)
Prof is willing to answer every question during lessons or through emails.

In lessons, you might encounter something like constellations which you might find difficult (though they are pieces of cake for me as I have taken probability courses before). They are especially important if you want to go further in empirical research. Be prepared to spend more time on that. Again, I won't guarantee they might (or might not) appear in your exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance and participation in class (UG: 10%, PG: 0%)
Homework assignments (UG/PG: 30%)
Presentation (UG/PG: 10%)
Poster/paper (UG: 20% /  PG: 30%)
Final exam (UG/PG: 30%)

Some statistics:
HW: Mean: 78.95 High: 94.58 Low: 26.21
Participation: Mean: 4.79     High: 10 Low: 0 [No idea on how it is calculated]
Presentation: Mean: 8.75 High: 10 Low: 7.5
Final paper/poster: NA (will update on this!!)
Final exam: Mean: 33.8    High: 72.5   Low: 14.5
reviews.comment_workload:
Little.
Prepare to spend 30 minutes on each homework (5 in total in this semester). Some involve Visone, R, or just MCs.
Easy to earn 3 credits and enjoy the learning process.

reviews.author: PTMS
reviews.title: content is great grading is bad
reviews.comment_content:
講下social network analysis 嘅basics
例如centrality measures, network model, network formation 等等 詳細可以睇其他人嘅review
基本上就係講下network analysis 係social science嘅用處，現象同埋一啲基本嘅network analysis term&theory 咁
另外都會用到3~4個software :
Gephi, Visone, Rstudio, Netlogo
不過學嚟同考試唔太大關係，係用係homework同明啲concept(visualization 點嚟同algorithm 之類)多啲
reviews.comment_teaching:
幾好人
你有咩問題佢都願意答
上堂跟唔到都可以不斷咁repeat
上堂氣氛都輕鬆嘅
係email 好飄忽(10分鐘內覆又有，5日後覆都有....平均1日左右先會覆)
整體好nice同上堂都唔會悶
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance and participation in class (5%)
Homework assignments (5-6 throughout the semester) (20%)
Mid-term exam (20%)
Final exam (20%)
Poster (20%)
Presentation (15%)
哈哈哈都唔知點講好
平均分數都畀得幾高嘅，如果淨係睇分係幾好
但grading就......
佢係一科14人嘅科入面用grading curve 真係.....
其實用grading curve 無乜嘢
但問題14人入面又dean's list又pg
真係比較難above mean
overall 如果有mean 應該B-~B
好唔好grade 就你地自己決定啦
(PS 當然依個係今個sem 嘅case,不過因為network analysis 比較少見所以都多機會有唔係shss嘅人, 所以好唔好grade我諗係depends on 個個sem 有d 咩人讀)
reviews.comment_workload:
好多嘢做
homework 星期二派星期三教星期五交
一份可以由2個鐘至6個鐘不等
同埋因為好多都係用software
你要預啲gen 多幾次確定無set 錯嘢同埋如果係random要做多幾次先知無錯
依5份homework 係weekly嘅，會係midterm 前做晒
之後midterm 後就到project
project topic 係自己揀 而workload都係因為咁而唔同....
簡單嘅一個禮拜都ko
複雜可以三個禮拜佢都唔太滿意
所以一定要不斷咁搵佢去改 如果唔係就玩完

reviews.author: asdfghjkl;
reviews.comment_content: You learn about theories of social network analysis. Basically need to memorize a lot of terms. And you also need to learn how to use different computer programs in Social Network Analysis. The content is exactly what the title of the course suggests, you get a good grasp on what social network analysis is about. If you have an area about social network analysis that you are really interested about, you can talk to the Prof and she'll be really open to suggestions
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is good. She'll try to make the lectures and labs interactive. And if you have questions, you can always feel free to e-mail her or go to her office.
reviews.comment_grading: She said that she will not follow the school's grading curve and try to give everyone good grades. Absolute BS. At the end of the course, she will follow exactly the grading curve. If not, make your grade even worse. Because there are very few people in the course and many masters, you have to compete grades with these people
reviews.comment_workload:
Holy mother of god. Let me just tell you
First of all, every week, you will an assignment due and could take you up to 7-8 hours because you could easily get stuck on one question and then have no idea how to figure it out. And asshole TA will always find minuscule excuses to deduct marks on your answers. The assignment will be released to you on Tuesday, but really, you can only get started on it Wednesday because the materials you need to know how to complete the assignment will be taught in Wednesday's lab lecture. And assignments are always due on Friday, which gives you a whole 48 hours to complete the assignment. How humanizing. Better yet, this happens every single week except the week of midterm. So you complete 10 or 11 assignments in total throughout the semester.

For the group project, my team and I pulled around 4 all nighters in total. There were multiple components, you have to do - make a poster in which first you hand in to receive feedback and then you hand in for a grade. And you also give a presentation. The project is absolute anal because you won't know what is going on most of the time as very guidance is given. And don't forget, toward the end of the semester, while you painstakingly work on the poster which you have no clue wtf is going on, you still need to spare 7-8 hours on the assignments.

All of this is excluding a midterm and a final

reviews.author: Roshan
reviews.title: Tedious Homework tasks and very specific grading
reviews.comment_content:
Not about social media at all - common misconception

Talks about networks between individuals and what can be extracted from different types of relationships.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great teacher, extremely helpful and very active
After semester moved online she offered to personally skype individuals who needed help for projects.
reviews.comment_grading: TA marks very harshly --> you need to use exact terminology and specifics from the handout given in the first lesson.
reviews.comment_workload:
7 Homework tasks (very annoying have to be R-studio God, lots of hidden tricks )
No midterm
Poster - group work not too bad
Final - canceled
